questions.text: The most common histological type of thyroid cancer is
questions.solution:
Women <40 years; C. Papillary carcinoma <4cm (Ref::Schwartz 1543/10th edition)

  • Based on AGES and AMES scoring systems.

AMES system

  • Age : Men < 40 years, Women < 50 years- Low risk
  • Metastasis
  • Extrathyroidal spread
  • Size ( < 5 cm low risk; > 5 cm high risk)

choices.text: Cold nodule on thyroid scan is diagnostic of malignancy
FNAC is the investigation of choice
The patient should undergo hemithyroidectomy if FNAC report is inconclusive
Indirect laryngoscopy be done in the preoperative period to assess mobility of vocal cords

questions.text: A 45-years old male presents with 4X4 cm, mobile right solitary thyroid nodule of 5 months. The patient is euthyroid. The following statements about his management are true except:
questions.solution:
Cold nodule on thyroid scan is diagnostic of malignancy (Ref: Schwartz 10/e p1537)

  • All thyroid surgeries should be preceded by ENT opinion for IDL scopy to look for Vocal cord paralysis.
  • About 3% cases will have occult Vocal cord paralysis ( RLN paralysis) and must be documented for Medico legal purpose before surgery

questions.text: Most common solitary thyroid nodule is:
questions.solution:
Solitary Nodule Thyroid : Differential diagnosis:

  • Colloid goitre ( m/c cause)- 60%
  • Follicular Adenoma thyroid :Autonomous  functioning  of  the  nodule without any stimulation by TSH or thyroid stimulating antibodies. – 30%
  • Dominant nodule of multinodular goitre
  • Cyst
  • Carcinoma thyroid
  • Lymphoma
  • Thyroiditis - Hashimotos, Reidel's, dequervains

choices.text: Colloid goiter mostly presents as hyperthyroidism
Thyroid storm, the clinical features are primarily due to increased thyroxine
Excess calcium intake can lead to hyperthyroidism
Goiter more than 5 percent of population is endemic goiter

questions.text: Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
• Colloid goiter may present as hypothyroid most commonly.
  • Calcium intake has nothing to do with thyroid.
  • Thyroid storm is due to decompensated hyperthyroidism and increased thyroxine* but the clinical features are primarily due to sympathetic overactivity**
  • Excess iodides can lead to hyperthyroidism- JodBasedow’s Thyrotoxicosis.
  • More than 5% of thyroid swellings in community is due to Endemic cause.

choices.text: 99 m-Tc scan should be performed to determine whether the nodules are hypofunctioning or hyperfunctioning
Functional thyroid nodules are usually benign
All nodules >4 cm should be resected irrespective of cytology
FNAC should be performed for allnodules >1 cm in diameter

questions.text: A 12-year old girl presents with nodular goiter. Which of the following statements regarding her evaluation and management is incorrect?
questions.solution:
( ref. Schwartz 10th edition Page 1358)

  • Functioning thyroid nodules are usually benign. Very rarely malignancy ( Follicular carcinoma -1% ) can produce hyper functioning thyroid nodule.
  • FNAC must be performed in all swellings.
  • Size > 4 cm is not an indication for surgery. Surgery is decided based on the FNAC report.

questions.text: Dancing carotid is seen in:
questions.solution:
( Ref. Bailey and Love Page 756 /26th edition)

  • Most common manifest of Toxicosis- Sinus Tachycardia
  • Order of appearance of arrhythmias- Multiple Extrasystoles followed by Paroxysmal atrial tachycardia followed by Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation and Persistent Atrial Fibrillation not responding to Digoxin.
  • Means – Lerman Scratch**- Systolic scratch sound heard in 2nd Intercostal Space during expiration
  • Dancing carotids due to hyperdynamic circulation seen in – Aortic regurgitation and Thyrotoxicosis

questions.text: During thyroidectomy, inferior thyroid artery is ligated at:
questions.solution:
(Schwartz 10/e p1553-1554)

RLN and Thyroid surgery:

  • The course of the right RLN is more oblique than the left RLN.
  • The nerves can be most consistently identified at the level of the cricoid cartilage
  • The inferior thyroid vessels are dissected, skeletonized, ligated, and divided as close to the surface of the thyroid gland as possible to minimize devascularization of the parathyroids (extracapsular dissection) or injury to the RLN.
  • The RLN is most vulnerable to injury in the vicinity of the ligament of Berry.
  • The nerve often passes through this structure along with small crossing arterial and venous branches (Fig.).
  • Any bleeding in this area should be controlled with gentle pressure before carefully identifying the vessel and ligating it.
  • Use of the electrocautery should be avoided in proximity to the RLN.

questions.text: A person has fever and pain in thyroid gland. True statement(s) is/are:
questions.solution:
This is a case of Subacute- De quervain’s thyroiditis:

  • Early stages there will be hyperthyroidism
  • Euthyroid phase follows
  • Finally hypothyroidism happens.
  • Resolution and return to Euthyroid state occurs in > 90% patients.

Laboratory findings:

  • ESR is markedly elevated
  • Anti thyroid antibodies- Low
  • T3 and T4 will be elevated initially / TSH will be low
  • RAIU is decreased* ( Important distinguishing feature from Graves disease**)

FNAC shows- Giant multinucleated cells**  infiltration***

questions.text: 20 years women comes with a mass in the left breast past 6 months. There are no associated symptoms. Examination shows a freely mobile mass not attached to the overlying skin or underlying tissue. The possible diagnosis is
questions.solution:
( Ref. Bailey and Love page 807)

  • Painless freely mobile mass in young female breast is commonly fibroadenoma.
  • Fibroadenoma is not premalignant.

choices.text: Breast mass but no lymph node palpable
Breast lump with palpable axillary lymph node

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is done only in
questions.solution:
(Ref Bailey and Love 26th edition Page 815)

Indications for SNB:

  • Indicated for early breast cancer in which lymph nodes are not detectable clinically or by imaging way. ( Palpable nodes we can take FNAC to confirm the malignancy)

Contraindications for SNB:

  • T3/T4 tumors with No nodes clinically
  • Inflammatory breast cancer
  • Palpable axillary nodes
  • Prior axillary or breast surgery because the lymphatics will be disturbed in it’s order.
  • After pre op Chemotherapy
  • In pregnancy.

questions.text: The following muscles are infiltrated by cancer breast except
questions.solution:
(Ref Sabiston 20th edition 843)

The following muscles can be infiltrated by malignancy in breast:

  • MC-Pectoralis major
  • Pectoralis minor
  • Serratus anterior
  • Intercostal muscles

T4a is staging known for Chest wall involvement which includes- Pectoralis minor, Serratus anterior and Intercostal muscles except Pectoralis major*

Latissimus Dorsi is not infiltrated by cancer breast- that’s why we use it for LD flaps in breast reconstruction.

questions.text: The feature of Nipple inversion occurs due to involvement of
questions.solution:
( Ref. Bailey and Love Page 801)

Nipple retraction:

  • Simple nipple inversion (Benign Horizontal inversion)- Occurs at puberty due to unknown etiology. Bilateral in 25% cases.
  • Slit like retraction- Duct ectasia/ Periductal mastitis
  • Circumferential- Carcinoma
  • Nipple inversion is due to shortening of Subareolar ducts- hence a complete division of these ducts is needed to correct it cosmetically* (Ref. Schwartz 10th edition Page 511)

questions.text: Latest method 'Gail model' of risk assessment is for
questions.solution:
(Ref. Schwartz principles of surgery, 10thed p-512)

Because of the increased risk of breast cancer in US- Gail developed a most commonly used model to predict the cumulative risk of breast cancer**. It includes the following factors*

  • Age
  • Age at menarche
  • Age at 1st child birth
  • Number of breast biopsy specimens
  • History of atypical hyperplasia
  • Number of 1st degree relatives with breast cancer
    • A scoring is calculated by a software based on these and predicts the 5 year risk and life time risk of breast cancer**

For Extra Edge – Know the other similar models used for cancer breast:

  • Clauss model
  • BRCAPRO model
  • Tyrer- Cuzick model

questions.text: All of the following are poor prognostic markers of CA Breast except-
questions.solution:
(Ref.Schwartz 10th edition page 536)

Poor Prognostic factors of Breast Cancer:

Tumor related factors:

  • Nodal status- Increased
  • Size and Grade of tumor- High
  • Lympho vascular invasion
  • Hormone Receptor- Negative
  • High Pathological staging
  • DNA Ploidy, S Phase fraction+
  • Her 2 /neu overexpression
  • Intraductal component+

Host related factors:

  • Young age
  • Menopausal status
  • Family History
  • Breast cancer History
  • Nutrition

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency as a case of head injury, following a head on collision road traffic accident. His BP is 90/60 mmHg. Tachycardia is present. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: • In a poly trauma if there is a low BP it is mostly from Abdominal bleed > Thoracic Bleed*

choices.text: Insertion of abdominal drain followed by laparotomy

questions.text: A patient with abdominal injury presents to the emergency department with signs of signs of peritonitis and shock. Air-way and breathing were secured and IV fluids were started with 2 large bore cannulas. The next line of management should be:
Which of the following is used to define penetrating neck injury?
questions.solution:
(Ref: Sabiston 19/e p445-446)

  • Neck injuries are divided into superficial and deep based on the breach in the platysma*

questions.text: A man comes to emergency with stab injury to left flank. He has stable vitals. What would be the next step in management:
questions.solution:
(Ref: Sabiston 19/e p456)

  • A penetrating Trauma abdomen is managed conservatively if peritoneum is not breached on local exploration and if they are hemodynamically stable.
  • In all such cases advise - Triple Contrast CT ( IV, Oral and Rectal Contrast)

questions.text: A patient with stab injury to anterior abdomen presents with a tag of omentum protruding through the abdominal wall near the umbilicus. On evaluation he is hemodynamically stable and shows no signs of peritonitis. Initial management of patient should involve:
In a blast injury, which of the following organ is least vulnerable to the blast wave?
questions.solution: (Ref: Sabiston 19/e p612-613)

questions.text: A child presents in causality in stable condition after a blunt abdominal trauma associated with splenic trauma. Treatment of choice is:
Commonest cause of death in penetrating injury of chest:
questions.solution: (Ref: Sabiston 19/e p612-613)

choices.text: Cardiac tamponade is likely to be present
Immediate emergency room thoracotomy should be done
Echocardiogram should be done to confirm pericardial blood
The entry wound should be sealed with an occlusive dressing

questions.text: A 40-years old man brought to the emergency room with a stab injury to the chest. On examination patient is found to be hemodynamically stable. The neck veins are engorged and the heart sounds are muffled. The following statements are true for this patient except:
questions.solution:
(Ref: Sabiston 19/e p1667)

  • Patient is in BECK’ S Triad: Pericardial Tamponade*
  • Muffled heart sounds*
  • Distended neck veins*
  • Hypotension*
  • Treatment- needle pericardiocentesis is done as emergency and shifted to theatre to do Surgical pericardiotomy ( treatment of choice).
  • Emergency room thoracotomy is not done- Patient is shifted to theatre to do thoracotomy*

questions.text: Sitaram a 40-years old man, met with an accident and comes to emergency department with engorged neck veins, pallor, rapid pulse and chest pain Diagnosis is:
Regarding familial adenomatous polyp all are true except
questions.solution:
• Colorectal cancer develops from age of 20 years onwards.
  • All of them will die at 40 years if not intervened.
  • 2nd MC cancer is Duodenal Periampullary cancers

choices.text: Adenoma is the m/c Benign tumor
Carcinoid is the MC tumor of Small intestine now
Palliative surgery is done for small bowel liver metastasis

questions.text: Regarding Small Bowel tumor - False statement
questions.solution:
• Latest Sabiston:
  • MC Small bowel Tumor: Mets
  • MC primary Malignant tumor- Adenocancer ( Duodenum MC)
  • MC Benign Tumor- Adenoma > Leiomyoma

questions.text: Following are features of Crohn's disease except
questions.solution:
• Even though Crypt abscess is seen in CD – Its more common in Ulcerative colitis.
  • Odd man out here is Crypt abscess, all others are seen in CD

choices.text: Secondary to swallowing of tubercle bacilli
Pulled up caecum on barium follow through

questions.text: Regarding hyperplastic tuberculosis the following is true
questions.solution:
• Primary TB= Hyperplastic TB= M.bovis in uncooked milk
  • Secondary TB= Ulcerative TB= M.TB Bacilli swallowing

questions.text: The SQUID is used to detect
questions.solution: • Super Quantum Interfence device - for non invasive method of detecting mesenteric ischemia

questions.text: Malignant Carcinoid syndrome - False statement
questions.solution: • Among all carcinoids Appendix rarely produces mets and Carcinoid syndrome. More common with Ileum

choices.text: If perforation occurs in <24 hours of onset

questions.text: Diffuse peritonitis following appendicitis occur
questions.solution: • As omentum will not be covering inflammatory area in 24 hours there is diffuse sepsis

questions.text: m/c cause of intestinal obstruction in age group of 2 years
questions.solution:
• Red currant Jelly Stools+
  • Claw Sign+
  • Le dance sign+

questions.text: Bishop koop operation is done for
questions.solution:
• Initial treatment is with Mypaque Enema.
  • 2nd Line treatment is Bishop koop surgery

questions.text: Normal fluid levels in abdomen on Plain X ray
questions.solution:

  • Normal vertical diameter= 2.5 cm

questions.text: 35 Female presented with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer, has a 2x2 cm lump in the right upper outer quadrant without any evidence of axillary nodes. Which of the following will be the treatment modality of choice?
questions.solution: Patient with high risk criteria like BRCA mutation carriers, family history of breast cancer, previous contralateral breast cancer all should undergo Modified radical mastectomy.  BCS is a relative contraindication in such cases.

questions.text: Tumor markers used in monitoring breast cancers are all except
questions.solution:
The following tumor markers are useful in monitoring breast cancers

CEA, CA 15-3, CA 27.29.  CA 125 is useful in monitoring ovarian cancers.

choices.text: BCS + ALND + Oncoplastic Surgery + WBRT + Adjuvant therapies

questions.text: 40 female with a lump in the right breast lower quadrant of size 3x2cm with ipsilateral mobile axillary nodes. Core needle biopsy revealed ductal adenocarcinoma, ER+ve and HER2 -ve tumor. Ideal management in this situation is?
questions.solution: If the question had been tumor in the upper quadrant, there is no need for Oncoplastic surgery. Whenever the tumor is in lower quadrant, there is high chance of nipple distortion and poor cosmetic outcome, so an Oncoplastic Surgery is contemplated.

questions.text: All of the following flaps are used in breast reconstruction except
questions.solution: Following Breast surgeries, the reconstruction options will be using a Lattismus Dorsi flap (LD flap), TRAM flap (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Muscle), DIEP flap (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator flap). Obviously PMMC (Pectoralis Major MyoCutaneous flap) cannot be used.)

questions.text: BCS can still be a possibility in
questions.solution: BCS is not possible in Locally advanced and Metastatic breast cancers. Hence B, C and D are incorrect. T3N1 although a LABC disease, if Neoadjuvant chemotherapy has Complete Response, BCS is still a possibility. In such cases, Prechemo wire localization of the tumor is essential.

choices.text: Level III nodes includes Infraclavicular nodes
Halsteadian ligament is the superomedial limit of axillary dissection
Medial pectoral nerve is medial to lateral pectoral nerve
Intercostobrachial Nerve is usually sacrificed in MRM

questions.text: Regarding Surgical Anatomy of Breast, FALSE is
questions.solution: Medial pectoral nerve is lateral to Lateral pectoral nerve.  Rest options are correct.

choices.text: Free fluid collection in Pleural cavity
Pancreatic stenting is to be done
Percutaneous drainage under image guidance is necessary

questions.text: Which one of the following regarding Pancreatic effusion is correct? (UPSC 2018)
questions.solution:
(ref. Bailey and Love 27th Edition Page 1228)

Pancreatic Effusion:

  • Encapsulated collection in Pleural cavity.
  • Concomitant Pancreatic ascites present
  • Connection may be present with intra abdominal collection seen.
  • Percutaneous drainage is done under USG guidance

questions.text:
Which of the statements regarding Calot's triangle are correct?
1. Common hepatic duct forms the medial boundary of the Calot's triangle
2. Inferior surface of the right lobe of the liver forms the superior boundary of Calot's triangle
3. Right hepatic artery is usually found as a content of the Calot's triangle
4. Cystic duct and medial border of gall bladder forms the lateral border of Calot's triangle
Select the correct answer using the code given below: ( UPSC 2019)
questions.solution:
( Ref. Surgery Sixer Page 543)

Calot's triangle Boundaries:

  • Inferior/ Lateral- Cystic duct and GB.
  • Medial- Common hepatic duct
  • Above- Cystic artery ( Some books like Bailey mentions Wrongly LIVER)

questions.text:
Consider the following statements regarding Opportunistic post-splenectomy infections (OPSI):
1. Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis and Streptococcus pneumoniae are the most common causative agents
2. Risk is greatest in the patients who have undergone splenectomy for trauma
3. Risk is greatest within the first 2-3 years following splenectomy
4. Prophylactic vaccination should be done 2 weeks prior to elective splenectomy
Which of the statements given above are correct? ( UPSC 2019)
questions.solution:
(Ref. Surgery Sixer 4th Edition page 677)

  • Direct line from Surgery Sixer- Risk of OPSI is more common in people who undergo splenectomy for Haematological indications than in Trauma*
  • Prophylactic vaccines must be given 2 weeks before elective surgery.

questions.text: 65 year old female presented with increased SGOT, SGPT , Bilirubin, Alkaline phosphatase. She has the following findings in USG -Sclerotic Atrophic Gall bladder, Large impacted stone in CBD, Distended CBD with dilated intrahepatic radicles. What is the Best treatment?
questions.solution:
( Ref. Surgery Sixer 4th Edition page 548)

  • The Best method to manage the CBD stone is ERCP, Sphincterotomy and Stone removal.
  • The question based on the Protocol for CBD stone Shown below.

questions.text: Which is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm?
questions.solution:
(Ref. Surgery Sixer 4th Edition Page 443)

  • MC functioning endocrine neoplasm of pancreas- Insulinoma
  • MC endocrine neoplasm in MEN -1 Syndrome- Gastrinoma
  • MC malignant endocrine neoplasm- gastrinoma
  • MC neuroendocrine tumor- Non functioning tumors

questions.text: What is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN1 syndrome>
questions.solution:
(Ref Surgery Sixer 4th Edition Page 968)

MEN-1 Syndrome (Wermer Syndrome)

  • Autosomal Dominant syndrome
  • 2/ 1 lakh population Prevalence.
  • 80% cases have Truncated menin protein** and result in oncogenesis

Clinical features:

  • Affects 3 P- Parathyroid (90%-MC), Pituitary and Pancreas.
  • 90% have Hyperparathyroidism due to Multiglandular hyperplasia*
  • 2nd MC manifest is Neuroendocrine tumor of Pancreas and Duodenum. ( 30-80%)
  • Carcinoids in Thymus and Bronchus
  • Pituitary adenomas- MC prolactinoma ( 15%- 30%)
  • Male and Female equally affected.
  • MC pancreatic tumor is Gastrinoma**
  • MC cause of mortality in MEN-1 is NET from Duodenal and pancreatic tumors or Intra thoracic carcinoids.
  • MEN 1 manifests from age of 5 years*
  • Biochemical surveillance to start at below ages:
  • 5 years: Prolactin level
  • 8 years: PTH and Calcium Level
  • 20 years: Gastrin, Chromogranin, Glucagon and Proinsulin

 

Hyperparathyroidism:

  • MC manifest in MEN -1
  • Due to multiglandular hyperplasia**
  • MC in 2nd decade*
  • 1st Biochemical abnormality noted is Hypercalcemia*
  • Enlargement is asymmetrical** ( Figure 8.1)


Figure 8.1. Parathyroid Hyperplasia in MEN 1

  • Treatment : 2 options:
  • Total Parathyroidectomy with heterotopic implantation of one parathyroid in Brachioradialis muscle
  • Subtotal ( removal of 3 and half glands)- Advantages are single incision and absence of transient Hypocalcemia which may be seen in Total Parathyroidectomy**

Entero pancreatic NET :

  • 2nd MC manifest is NET of Duodenum and Pancreas. ( 30-80% incidence)
  • NET in MEN-1 are multifocal usually.
  • MC site in Intra duodenal mucosa > Pancreas.
  • CT scan, EUS, Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy ( SRS ) are used to localize the tumors.
  • SASI – Selective arterial secretagogue Injection is Invasive but most sensitive**
  • Most common (40-60% ) NET are Gastrinomas and of them about 80% are malignant**
  • Of the location- Pancreatic gastrinomas produce more of liver mets compared to Duodenal Gastrinomas.
  • Excision is the treatment for Gastrinomas.
  • Insulinomas are very less in incidence ( 10-25%)
  • Only 10% of insulinomas are malignant.

 

Pituitary Adenomas:

  • Anterior pituitary adenomas are 15-30% incidence in MEN-1
  • MC Pituitary adenoma is Prolactinoma**-
  • Clinical features : Amenorrhea, Galactorrhea, Hypogonadism in males*
  • Acromegaly and Cushing Disease seen

 

Other lesions:

  • Type 2 Gastric Carcinoids
  • Thymic Carcinoids
  • Bronchial Carcinoids
  • Lipomas
  • Facial angiofibromas
  • Collagenomas
  • Meningiomas
  • Ependymomas of CNS
  • Adreno cortical nodules and Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia ( 30%)

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.text: A 5 years old male child with acute fulminant liver failure. Which one of the following criteria are not included in the KING's college criteria for Liver transplant?
questions.solution: ( Ref. Surgery Sixer 4th Edition page 591)

questions.text: What is the Modified Child Pugh class for patient who has a serum bilirubin of 2.5 mg/dl , Serum albumin 3g/dl, Prothrombin time increased 5 seconds. Moderate ascites is present but there is Grade 2 encephalopathy.
questions.solution:
( Ref. Surgery Sixer 4th Edition Page 492)

Based on the Modified Child Pugh Scoring System



  • Grade A: 5-6
  • Grade B: 7-9
  • Grade C: 10-15 points

From the question;

  • Serum Bilirubin -2.5 mg/dl= 2 points
  • Serum Albumin- 3 mg/dl= 2 points
  • PT increased 5 seconds= 2 point
  • Moderate ascites= 3 points
  • Encephalopathy Grade 2= 2 Points

Total Points= 11 Points – Hence Child C grade**

questions.text: A patient diagnosed as Carcinoma Uncinate process presents with sudden abdominal pain on one day. The tumor has infiltrated into
questions.solution: • The vessels closely related to Uncinate process are SMA and SMV. Infiltration of tumor into SMA can cause mesenteric ischemia and abdominal pain.

questions.text: 35 years old male presents with recurrent episodes of fever with chills and rigors. On examination Jaundice is seen. MRCP image is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
(Ref. Surgery Sixer 4th Edition Page 551)

The history is clearly leading to Primary sclerosing cholangitis:

  • Age group-40 years
  • Males> females
  • Intermittent Jaundice+ Weight loss+ Fatigue+ Pruritus+ Pain abdomen
  • Associated with Reidel’s Thyroiditis or Retroperitoneal Fibrosis.
  • 10% cases lead to Cholangiocarcinoma*
  • Gold Standard Investigation is ERCP which shows multiple dilatation and stricture of Biliary radicles.

The image in picture is MRCP showing similar finding.
